questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Singer's nodule? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: A
options.text: Laser therapy is the treatment of choice

options.label: B
options.text: Requires excision as it is potentially malignant

options.label: D
options.text: It occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3

questions.correct_answer: D. It occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) It occurs at the junction of the anterior 1/3rd and posterior 2/3rd

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Singer's nodules (also called Screamer's nodes) appear symmetrically on the free edge of vocal cords at the junction of anterior one-third with posterior two-thirds. This specific location is the area of maximum vibration of the cord during phonation, making it subject to maximum trauma. They develop due to vocal abuse or misuse when a person speaks in unnatural low tones for prolonged periods or at high intensities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Laser therapy is the treatment of choice: This is incorrect. Early cases of vocal nodules are treated conservatively through voice rest and speech therapy, especially in children. Surgery is only required for large nodules or nodules of long standing in adults. Even when surgery is indicated, it can be performed either with cold instruments or laser - neither being designated as the "treatment of choice."
  • • Option A. Laser therapy is the treatment of choice:
  • • Option B. Requires excision as it is potentially malignant: This is incorrect. Singer's nodules are non-neoplastic, benign lesions that form due to trauma from vocal abuse. They have no malignant potential. They develop through a process of submucosal edema and hemorrhage that undergoes hyalinization and fibrosis.
  • • Option B. Requires excision as it is potentially malignant:
  • • Option C. Most common symptom is pain: This is incorrect. Hoarseness is the most common complaint in patients with vocal nodules. Vocal fatigue and pain in the neck on prolonged phonation may occur as secondary symptoms, but they are not the primary presenting complaint.
  • • Option C. Most common symptom is pain:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Singer's nodules develop at the junction of anterior 1/3 and posterior 2/3 of vocal cords due to vocal abuse, primarily causing hoarseness, and are initially managed with conservative treatment including voice rest and speech therapy.

questions.text: An elderly gentleman has presented with symptoms of difficulty swallowing, regurgitation, bad breath, and cough. He also exhibits bilateral lung crepitations upon examination. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Zenker's Diverticulum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through Killian's dehiscence (a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle). This condition typically affects patients over 60 years of age, matching our elderly patient's demographic. The classic symptoms include dysphagia (difficulty swallowing), regurgitation of undigested food (especially at night when recumbent), halitosis (bad breath), and cough with aspiration pneumonia (explaining the bilateral lung crepitations).
  • • Visual Support
  • • Zenker's diverticulum occurs when herniation of pouch starts in the midline. It is at first behind the esophagus and then comes to lie on its left. The mouth of the sac is wider than the opening of esophagus, so food preferentially enters the sac.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Schatzki Ring: This is a narrow ring of tissue at the lower end of the esophagus and would not cause regurgitation of undigested food or aspiration pneumonia. It typically presents with intermittent dysphagia for solids only, not the constellation of symptoms described.
  • • Option A. Schatzki Ring:
  • • Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus: This is a motility disorder (diffuse esophageal spasm) characterized by non-peristaltic contractions. While it can cause dysphagia, it does not lead to regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia as seen in this patient.
  • • Option C. Corkscrew Esophagus:
  • • Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome: This condition is characterized by hypochromic microcytic anemia, dysphagia, and esophageal webs. It typically affects women in their 40s and 50s, not elderly men. It is not associated with regurgitation, halitosis, or aspiration pneumonia.
  • • Option D. Plummer-Vinson Syndrome:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zenker's diverticulum should be suspected in elderly patients presenting with dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, halitosis, and respiratory complications due to aspiration, as the pouch traps food that can later be regurgitated and aspirated.

questions.text: Endolymphatic hydrops is typically associated with which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)  Meniere's disease

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathophysiological basis of Meniere's disease. It is characterized by excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear, causing distension of the membranous labyrinth. This directly correlates with the classic clinical symptoms seen in Meniere's disease: episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, and tinnitus and aural fullness.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Otosclerosis: This is a condition with irregular spongy bone formation around the oval window, leading to fixation of the stapes footplate. It causes a conductive hearing loss due to impeded sound transmission. Otosclerosis has no relationship with endolymphatic hydrops or the balance mechanism.
  • • Option B. Otosclerosis:
  • • Option C. Acoustic Neuroma: This is a benign tumor that arises from the inferior vestibular nerve in the internal auditory canal. It causes progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. It is not associated with endolymphatic hydrops or fluctuating symptoms like those seen in Meniere's disease.
  • • Option C. Acoustic Neuroma:
  • • Option D. Cholesteatoma: This is a "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear cleft. It causes a destructive process in the middle ear with bone erosion and conductive hearing loss. It has no connection with endolymphatic hydrops.
  • • Option D. Cholesteatoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endolymphatic hydrops is the hallmark pathological finding in Meniere's disease, causing episodic symptoms of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and aural fullness due to increased pressure in the inner ear's endolymphatic system.

questions.text: A group organized a mass gathering on handwashing awareness. Arrange the steps in the correct chronological sequence: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.correct_answer: B. Awareness – Interest – Evaluation – Trial – Adoption
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Awareness – Interest – Evaluation – Trial – Adoption

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence for behavior change adoption in health education:
  • ➤ Awareness → Interest → Evaluation → Trial → Adoption (AITA)

questions.text: International health agency - DANIDA is supporting which health program of India? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Blindness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The DANIDA (Danish International Development Agency) provides support specifically to India's National Program for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment.

questions.text: All of the following are true about Kleine-Levin syndrome (KLS), EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Kleine-Levin Syndrome (KLS) , sometimes referred to as “Sleeping Beauty Syndrome,” is a rare sleep disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of:
  • • Kleine-Levin Syndrome (KLS)
  • • “Sleeping Beauty Syndrome,”
  • • recurrent episodes
  • • Hypersomnia (sleeping up to 18–20 hours a day), Hyperphagia (excessive eating), Hypersexuality , and Behavioral disinhibition .
  • • Hypersomnia (sleeping up to 18–20 hours a day),
  • • Hypersomnia
  • • Hyperphagia (excessive eating),
  • • Hyperphagia
  • • Hypersexuality , and
  • • Hypersexuality
  • • Behavioral disinhibition .
  • • Behavioral disinhibition
  • • These episodes typically last days to weeks, and in between episodes, individuals return to baseline functioning. KLS most often begins in male adolescents, usually between the ages of 10 -21years. KLS is marked by hyperphagia, not reduced appetite (Anorexia). The presence of voracious eating during episodes is a defining characteristic that helps differentiate it from other conditions with excessive sleepiness.
  • • baseline
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sleeping Beauty Syndrome: This is a well-known nickname for KLS, reflecting the extended sleep durations during episodes. Option C. Hypersomnia: This is a core diagnostic feature . Patients often sleep nearly continuously for days, only waking to eat or use the bathroom. Option D. Hypersexuality: Frequently observed in KLS. It includes increased libido, inappropriate sexual behavior, or disinhibition during episodes.
  • • Option A. Sleeping Beauty Syndrome: This is a well-known nickname for KLS, reflecting the extended sleep durations during episodes.
  • • Option A. Sleeping Beauty Syndrome:
  • • Option C. Hypersomnia: This is a core diagnostic feature . Patients often sleep nearly continuously for days, only waking to eat or use the bathroom.
  • • Option C. Hypersomnia:
  • • core diagnostic feature
  • • Option D. Hypersexuality: Frequently observed in KLS. It includes increased libido, inappropriate sexual behavior, or disinhibition during episodes.
  • • Option D. Hypersexuality:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kleine-Levin Syndrome is defined by episodic hypersomnia, hyperphagia, and hypersexuality, with complete resolution between episodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is commonly used for maintenance therapy in opioid abuse? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Buprenorphine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methadone and buprenorphine are long-acting opioids used for maintenance therapy in opioid addiction. They replace the addictive opioid to prevent withdrawal symptoms. To treat withdrawal symptoms: Diazepam (a benzodiazepine) is used for seizures. Clonidine or beta blockers are used for sympathetic symptoms. Naltrexone is used to prevent relapse in opioid addiction.
  • ➤ Methadone and buprenorphine are long-acting opioids used for maintenance therapy in opioid addiction. They replace the addictive opioid to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
  • ➤ Methadone
  • ➤ buprenorphine
  • ➤ To treat withdrawal symptoms: Diazepam (a benzodiazepine) is used for seizures. Clonidine or beta blockers are used for sympathetic symptoms.
  • ➤ Diazepam (a benzodiazepine) is used for seizures. Clonidine or beta blockers are used for sympathetic symptoms.
  • ➤ Diazepam (a benzodiazepine) is used for seizures.
  • ➤ Diazepam
  • ➤ Clonidine or beta blockers are used for sympathetic symptoms.
  • ➤ Clonidine
  • ➤ Naltrexone is used to prevent relapse in opioid addiction.
  • ➤ Naltrexone

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations, shortness of breath, and dizziness. The child has no significant past medical history. On examination, the heart rate is 220 beats per minute, blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and the child appears anxious but is otherwise stable. An ECG confirms the diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). What is the initial recommended dose of adenosine for this child? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 0.1 mg/kg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial recommended dose of adenosine for treating PSVT in children is 0.1 mg/kg, with a maximum dose of 6 mg. If the initial dose is ineffective, a higher dose of 0.2 mg/kg may be administered.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Hutchinson's triad? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hutchinson's triad is a set of clinical findings associated with congenital syphilis. The triad consists of three specific manifestations: Hutchinson's teeth (notched, widely spaced peg-shaped central incisors), interstitial keratitis (inflammation of the corneal stroma without involvement of the epithelium or endothelium), and sensorineural hearing loss (8th cranial nerve deafness).
  • • To remember - hutchinson's triad mnemonic - HID
  • • H Hutchinson's Incisors
  • • I Interstitial keratitis
  • • D Deafness
  • • Follicular conjunctivitis is not part of this classical triad and is more commonly associated with viral or chlamydial infections.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hutchinson's teeth - Correct component of Hutchinson's triad. These are characterized by notched, barrel-shaped permanent central incisors that are widely spaced and smaller than normal.
  • • Option B. Hutchinson's teeth
  • • Option C. Interstitial keratitis - Correct component of Hutchinson's triad. This is a non-ulcerative inflammation of the cornea that typically presents as bilateral (though often asymmetric) corneal clouding, causing photophobia and reduced vision.
  • • Option C. Interstitial keratitis
  • • Option D. Vestibular deafness - Correct component of Hutchinson's triad. This refers to sensorineural hearing loss resulting from damage to the 8th cranial nerve, which typically develops in late childhood in patients with congenital syphilis.
  • • Option D. Vestibular deafness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hutchinson's triad in congenital syphilis consists of dental abnormalities (Hutchinson's teeth), interstitial keratitis, and sensorineural hearing loss - representing the effects of Treponema pallidum infection on dental development, the eye, and the 8th cranial nerve.

questions.text: It is being planned to put posters in the whole city for health promotion. Which type of health education approach is this? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mass based

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Posters are a mass-based health education approach used for reaching large populations simultaneously with health messages.
  • ➤ Approaches For Health Communication
  • ➤ Approaches For Health Communication

questions.text: A surgical procedure is performed on the great saphenous vein located 2.5 cm anterior to the medial malleolus. Which nerve should be prevented from damage during the ligature? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein near the medial malleolus and is at risk of injury during surgical procedures in this region.

questions.text: A person missing from home is found wandering purposefully. He is well-groomed and denies having any amnesia. Most likely diagnosis is: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dissociative fugue is marked by sudden, unexpected travel away from home or familiar surroundings. During a fugue, individuals often appear well-groomed and behave in a seemingly normal, goal-directed way, which reflects preserved self-care and orientation. However, once the fugue ends, they usually experience amnesia for what occurred during the episode. While in the fugue state, they might not even recognize anything is wrong and may deny memory issues. These episodes can last from minutes to months, and some individuals may have recurrent fugues. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue is considered a specifier of dissociative amnesia.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Dissociative amnesia: This involves an inability to recall important personal information, usually related to trauma or stress, but it does not necessarily include the travel or wandering behavior seen in fugue states. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue has been made a subtype of dissociative amnesia. Option C. Schizophrenia: People with schizophrenia may wander, but it’s typically disorganized or bizarre rather than purposeful. There are other signs also like hallucinations, delusions, or negative symptoms. The person’s well-groomed appearance and coherent behavior is against this diagnosis. Option D. Dementia: Wandering can happen in dementia, but the onset is usually gradual, and the person often appears disheveled or confused. Dementia-related wandering stems from memory loss and impaired judgment, not dissociation. Plus, the sudden nature described in this case doesn't fit with how dementia typically presents.
  • • Option B. Dissociative amnesia: This involves an inability to recall important personal information, usually related to trauma or stress, but it does not necessarily include the travel or wandering behavior seen in fugue states. In DSM-5, dissociative fugue has been made a subtype of dissociative amnesia.
  • • Option B. Dissociative amnesia:
  • • Option C. Schizophrenia: People with schizophrenia may wander, but it’s typically disorganized or bizarre rather than purposeful. There are other signs also like hallucinations, delusions, or negative symptoms. The person’s well-groomed appearance and coherent behavior is against this diagnosis.
  • • Option C. Schizophrenia:
  • • Option D. Dementia: Wandering can happen in dementia, but the onset is usually gradual, and the person often appears disheveled or confused. Dementia-related wandering stems from memory loss and impaired judgment, not dissociation. Plus, the sudden nature described in this case doesn't fit with how dementia typically presents.
  • • Option D. Dementia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ If someone suddenly leaves home and ends up in a new place with intact self-care, normal-seeming behavior, and later has no memory of it, it must be dissociative fugu e —especially if there are no psychotic or neurocognitive symptoms present.
  • ➤ e

questions.text: The space between bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process is called: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hiatus Semilunaris

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The hiatus semilunaris is the gap between the bulla ethmoidalis and uncinate process. It represents a two-dimensional space with a width of approximately 1-2mm. The uncinate process is a hook-like structure that runs from anterosuperior to posteroinferior direction, with its sharp posterosuperior border running parallel to the anterior border of the bulla ethmoidalis, creating this distinctive gap.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Agger nasi : This is an elevation located just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. When pneumatized, it contains agger nasi cells which may communicate with the frontal recess, but it is not the space between the bulla and uncinate process.
  • • Option A. Agger nasi :
  • • Option B. Olfactory cleft: This refers to the superior part of the nasal cavity where the olfactory epithelium is located, between the upper part of the septum and superior turbinate. It has no relation to the bulla ethmoidalis or uncinate process.
  • • Option B. Olfactory cleft:
  • • Option C. Frontonasal duct: This is an incorrect term that was historically used to describe the drainage pathway from the frontal sinus. No true duct exists; rather, the frontal sinus drains through the frontal recess into the middle meatus.
  • • Option C. Frontonasal duct:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The hiatus semilunaris is a critical landmark in the ostiomeatal complex, serving as an important reference point during endoscopic sinus surgery and forming part of the pathway for drainage of the anterior group of paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: For OME, Myringotomy is done in which quadrant? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Antero-inferior

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), myringotomy is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. This location is specifically chosen because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding important structures. The antero-inferior quadrant is the safest area to make an incision as it avoids damage to the ossicles and other vital middle ear structures.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Antero-posterior : No such quadrant exists.
  • • Option B. Antero-posterior
  • • Option C. Postero-superior : This is the most dangerous quadrant for myringotomy as it contains the incus and stapes. Additionally, the chorda tympani nerve runs through this area, and facial nerve injury is a risk if the incision extends too deeply. This area is avoided for routine myringotomy.
  • • Option C. Postero-superior
  • • Option D. Postero-inferior : Although this quadrant is relatively safe compared to the postero-superior quadrant, it is not the preferred site for myringotomy. The round window niche is located in the posterior part of the middle ear, and damage to this structure could potentially affect inner ear function.
  • • Option D. Postero-inferior

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myringotomy for OME is performed in the antero-inferior quadrant because it provides optimal drainage while avoiding vital middle ear structures, ensuring both effectiveness and safety of the procedure.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT true about Alagille Syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Peroxisomal biogenesis disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alagille syndrome is an arterio-hepatic dysplasia characterized by bile duct paucity, butterfly vertebrae, distinctive facial features, and cardiac defects (particularly TOF and pulmonary stenosis), but it is not a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder.

questions.text: A person had a fall on an outstretched hand. He presented with pain and swelling at the base of the thumb. Which structure is most likely to be injured? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Scaphoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The scaphoid bone is the most common carpal bone injured in falls on an outstretched hand, especially when the patient presents with pain and swelling at the base of the thumb.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Pavor nocturnus except: (NEET PG 2017)

options.label: C
options.text: Return to sleep is often delayed due to fear

questions.correct_answer: C. Return to sleep is often delayed due to fear
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sleep terrors are NREM parasomnias that begin with a loud scream and intense autonomic arousal but are usually followed by quick return to sleep and no memory of the event . They differ from nightmares in their sleep stage origin, behavioral features, and recall after the episode.
  • ➤ Sleep terrors
  • ➤ quick return to sleep
  • ➤ no memory of the event

questions.text: Which condition is associated with the appearance of Brown sign? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Glomus tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Brown sign (also called pulsation sign) is specifically associated with glomus tumors. This sign is characterized by pulsation of the mass in the middle ear that can be observed through the tympanic membrane. Glomus tumors (paragangliomas) are highly vascular neoplasms that originate from paraganglionic tissue. Their vascularity results in visible pulsations that characterize the Brown sign.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Meniere's disease: This is characterized by endolymphatic hydrops with symptoms of episodic vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness. It is not associated with any visible pulsating mass or the Brown sign as it affects the inner ear rather than producing a middle ear mass.
  • • Option B. Meniere's disease:
  • • Option C. Acoustic neuroma: This is a benign tumor of the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) that typically presents with unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and sometimes vertigo. It develops in the internal auditory canal or cerebellopontine angle, not in the middle ear, and does not present with visible pulsations or Brown sign.
  • • Option C. Acoustic neuroma:
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis: This is characterized by abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to progressive conductive hearing loss. It does not present with a visible pulsating mass or Brown sign. The otoscopic findings in otosclerosis are typically normal or may show a pinkish hue through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign).
  • • Option D. Otosclerosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brown sign (pulsation sign) refers to visible pulsations of a middle ear mass seen through the tympanic membrane and is pathognomonic for glomus tumors due to their highly vascular nature.

questions.text: What will be the symptoms of a fracture at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anosmia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone can lead to anosmia due to damage to the olfactory nerves. This area is crucial for the sense of smell.

questions.text: The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome includes all of the following, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The classical triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) consists of cataract, deafness, and congenital heart defects (particularly Patent Ductus Arteriosus). This triad represents the most characteristic manifestations of maternal rubella infection during pregnancy, especially when infection occurs during the first trimester. While mental retardation can occur in children with CRS, it is not part of the classical diagnostic triad but rather an additional manifestation that may be present in severe cases.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cataract - Correct component of the CRS triad. Cataracts are typically bilateral but can be unilateral and develop from damage to the developing lens during embryogenesis.
  • • Option A. Cataract
  • • Option B. Deafness - Correct component of the CRS triad. Sensorineural hearing loss is the most common manifestation of CRS, affecting up to 80% of infected infants.
  • • Option B. Deafness
  • • Option C. Heart Defects - Correct component of the CRS triad. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common cardiac defect, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis and ventricular septal defects.
  • • Option C. Heart Defects

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic triad of Congenital Rubella Syndrome consists of cataracts, deafness, and congenital heart defects (primarily PDA). Additional manifestations may include microcephaly, mental retardation, purpuric rash ("blueberry muffin" appearance), hepatosplenomegaly, and intrauterine growth restriction.

questions.text: Under Integrated Disease Surveillance Program, which of the following diseases are covered under Sentinel surveillance? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) HIV and HBV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Under IDSP, sentinel surveillance specifically covers HIV, HBV, HCV, and environmental factors like air and water quality.
  • ➤ Integrated diseases surveillance project (IDSP)
  • ➤ Encompasses

questions.text: The marked structure secretes which hormone? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The adrenal medulla, the innermost part of the adrenal gland, is responsible for secreting adrenaline, a hormone essential for the body's acute stress response.

questions.text: During the surgical procedure for patent ductus arteriosus, which structure in close relation to it can be damaged? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left recurrent laryngeal nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is at significant risk of injury during surgical procedures for patent ductus arteriosus due to its close anatomical relationship with the ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: Constituents of nasal septum include all except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Perpendicular plate of palatine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The nasal septum is composed of both bony and cartilaginous components. The main constituents include the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone superiorly, the vomer posteroinferiorly, the quadrangular cartilage anteriorly, and the maxillary crest inferiorly. The perpendicular plate of the palatine bone is not a constituent of the nasal septum.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Vomer: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The vomer is a thin, flat bone that forms the posteroinferior portion of the nasal septum. It articulates with the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid superiorly and the maxillary crest inferiorly.
  • • Option A. Vomer:
  • • Option C. Quadrangular cartilage: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The quadrangular cartilage (septal cartilage) forms the major anterior portion of the nasal septum. It is attached to the perpendicular plate of the ethmoid posterosuperiorly and to the vomer posteroinferiorly.
  • • Option C. Quadrangular cartilage:
  • • Option D. Maxillary crest: This is a correct component of the nasal septum. The maxillary crest forms a ridge along the nasal floor that supports the inferior edge of the nasal septum. It is formed by the fusion of the palatine processes of the maxillae.
  • • Option D. Maxillary crest:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nasal septum consists of the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone, vomer, quadrangular cartilage, and maxillary crest, but does not include the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone.

questions.text: In which phase of clinical trials is drug dosing determined? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Phase 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The initial determination of drug dosing is primarily conducted during Phase 1 of clinical trials, where the safety and tolerability of the drug are assessed.

questions.text: Name the hormone secreted by the marked cell: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Calcitonin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The parafollicular cells (C cells) in the thyroid gland secrete calcitonin, a hormone that helps regulate calcium levels in the blood.

questions.text: At what age is handedness typically established in children? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Handedness, or hand preference, begins to emerge in early childhood and becomes progressively more established over time. According to developmental milestones, handedness begins to be established by 18 months but becomes fully established by 3 years of age. At this age, most children show a clear and consistent preference for using one hand (typically the right hand in approximately 85-90% of the population) for fine motor tasks such as drawing, cutting, and manipulating objects. While some hand preference may be observed earlier, 3 years marks the age when hand dominance is typically well-established and remains stable.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 2 years - Incorrect. While many children begin showing hand preference by 2 years, handedness is not yet fully established at this age. At 2 years, hand preference may still be inconsistent.
  • • Option A. 2 years
  • • Option C. 4 years - Incorrect. By 4 years, handedness has already been established for most children. At this age, children are refining their fine motor skills with their dominant hand rather than establishing dominance.
  • • Option C. 4 years
  • • Option D. 5 years - Incorrect. This is too late; hand dominance has been well-established by this age. By 5 years, children are typically using their dominant hand consistently for all fine motor tasks.
  • • Option D. 5 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Handedness typically becomes fully established by 3 years of age, with earlier signs of preference often visible by 18-24 months. Consistent hand dominance is an important developmental milestone and should be considered when assessing a child's fine motor skill development.

questions.text: In the diagnosis of Visceral Leishmaniasis, from which organ is the diagnostic yield the highest? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Splenic aspiration provides the highest diagnostic yield for visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar), with a sensitivity of 93-99%. The spleen contains the highest concentration of Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies or amastigotes), making it the most reliable site for parasite detection. The amastigotes can be visualized microscopically in splenic aspirate smears stained with Giemsa or Leishman stains. Despite its high sensitivity, splenic aspiration carries a risk of serious hemorrhage (0.1%) and is usually performed only in specialized centers with surgical backup.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Liver - Incorrect. While liver biopsy can be used for diagnosis, the sensitivity is lower (approximately 75-85%) compared to splenic aspiration. Additionally, liver biopsy carries risks of bleeding and bile leak.
  • • Option B. Liver
  • • Option C. Bone marrow aspirate - Incorrect. Bone marrow aspiration has lower sensitivity (60-85%) compared to splenic aspiration but is more commonly performed due to its relatively lower risk profile. It is often the first invasive diagnostic test performed.
  • • Option C. Bone marrow aspirate
  • • Option D. Lymph nodes - Incorrect. Lymph node aspiration has the lowest sensitivity (50-60%) among these options for diagnosing visceral leishmaniasis. It is useful primarily in patients with significant lymphadenopathy.
  • • Option D. Lymph nodes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Splenic aspiration provides the highest diagnostic yield for visceral leishmaniasis, but due to risk of hemorrhage, bone marrow aspiration is often performed first, with splenic aspiration reserved for cases where other methods have failed to provide a diagnosis.

questions.text: Middle radioulnar joint is a type of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Syndesmosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The middle radioulnar joint is classified as a syndesmosis, which is a type of fibrous joint connected by a sheet of fibrous tissue, such as the interosseous membrane.

questions.text: Which of the following are the first permanent teeth to erupt in children? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A. First Molar

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first permanent teeth to erupt in children are the first molars at approximately 6-7 years of age, often called the "6-year molars," which erupt before the shedding of primary teeth begins.

questions.text: A person’s father had colon cancer. He was having bloody stool. So, he just came for the check-up. Before, he had not undergone any screening. He was recommended to do colonoscopy screening. Screening is which level of prevention? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Secondary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Screening tests are part of secondary prevention, which focuses on early detection and prompt treatment of diseases before they progress to more severe stages.
  • ➤ Levels of Prevention of Disease

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not cause conductive hearing loss? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Endolymphatic Hydrops

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Endolymphatic hydrops is the pathological condition underlying Ménière's disease. It involves an excessive accumulation of endolymph in the inner ear's membranous labyrinth, particularly affecting the cochlea. This condition causes sensorineural hearing loss (not conductive) because it affects the sensory hair cells in the cochlea. The hearing loss in Ménière's disease is typically fluctuating and predominantly affects the lower frequencies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Otosclerosis : This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone formation around the stapes footplate, leading to its fixation in the oval window. This prevents normal transmission of sound vibrations from the middle ear to the inner ear, resulting in conductive hearing loss of up to 60 dB.
  • • Option A. Otosclerosis
  • • Option B. Serous otitis media : This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Also known as otitis media with effusion, it involves accumulation of non-purulent fluid in the middle ear space. This fluid impedes the movement of the tympanic membrane and ossicular chain, resulting in conductive hearing loss typically ranging from 20-40 dB.
  • • Option B. Serous otitis media
  • • Option D. Suppurative otitis media : This condition causes conductive hearing loss. Acute or chronic suppurative otitis media involves infection of the middle ear with purulent discharge. The presence of pus in the middle ear and/or perforation of the tympanic membrane interferes with sound transmission, resulting in conductive hearing loss.
  • • Option D. Suppurative otitis media

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endolymphatic hydrops (Ménière's disease) is an inner ear disorder causing sensorineural hearing loss, while conditions affecting the external or middle ear (otosclerosis, otitis media) cause conductive hearing loss by interfering with the mechanical transmission of sound to the inner ear.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Ataxia Telangiectasia is NOT true? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Selective absence of IgM

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ataxia Telangiectasia typically presents with progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasia of the conjunctiva and skin, elevated alpha-fetoprotein levels, and immunodeficiency (specifically IgA deficiency and impaired cell-mediated immunity), along with increased risk of malignancy and diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: All of the following are features of Ganser Syndrome, except: ( Neet PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ganser syndrome is a rare dissociative disorder most notable for the presence of "approximate answers"—a symptom known as vorbeigehen. Patients respond with incorrect but closely related answers that suggest an understanding of the question.
  • • The syndrome is also commonly associated with:
  • • Clouding of consciousness: manifesting as disorientation, confusion, amnesia, and impaired reality testing.
  • • Hallucinations : often visual or auditory, occurring in many cases.
  • • Hallucinations
  • • Somatic conversion symptoms: such as non-neurologic analgesia, shifting sensory deficits, or other functional neurologic signs sometimes described as "hysterical stigmata."
  • • Verbigeration is a senseless repetition of one or several sentences or phrases. For example, a patient continued to repeat the following sentences for hours “Life is amazing. God is great. Children will come to meet soon. Its not a feature of Ganser’s syndrome
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Approximate Answers: This is actually the defining feature of Ganser syndrome. These nearly correct but inaccurate responses distinguish the condition. Option B. Clouding of consciousness: A core component of Ganser syndrome. It often contributes to the presentation of confusion and impaired insight. Option C. Somatic conversion: Often seen in Ganser syndrome, especially in the form of conversion symptoms like numbness, non-anatomic sensory changes, or motor deficits that don’t follow neurologic patterns.
  • • Option A. Approximate Answers: This is actually the defining feature of Ganser syndrome. These nearly correct but inaccurate responses distinguish the condition.
  • • Option A. Approximate Answers:
  • • defining feature
  • • Option B. Clouding of consciousness: A core component of Ganser syndrome. It often contributes to the presentation of confusion and impaired insight.
  • • Option B. Clouding of consciousness:
  • • core component
  • • Option C. Somatic conversion: Often seen in Ganser syndrome, especially in the form of conversion symptoms like numbness, non-anatomic sensory changes, or motor deficits that don’t follow neurologic patterns.
  • • Option C. Somatic conversion:
  • • conversion symptoms

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ganser syndrome is best remembered by its hallmark triad:
  • ➤ Approximate answers (vorbeigehen) Clouding of consciousness Hallucinations It may also present with conversion symptoms, but verbigeration is not part of the typical clinical picture and is more aligned with psychotic disorders like schizophrenia.
  • ➤ Approximate answers (vorbeigehen)
  • ➤ Clouding of consciousness
  • ➤ Hallucinations It may also present with conversion symptoms, but verbigeration is not part of the typical clinical picture and is more aligned with psychotic disorders like schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient presents with an extremely painful lesion in the external ear accompanied by otorrhea that has not responded to antibiotics. Granulation tissue is observed in the external ear, and there is evidence of bony erosion along with facial nerve palsy. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malignant Otitis Externa

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation strongly indicates Malignant Otitis Externa (MOE), also known as necrotizing otitis externa. Key diagnostic features present in this case include: extreme pain in the external ear, otorrhea unresponsive to antibiotics, presence of granulation tissue in the external ear canal, bony erosion, facial nerve palsy, and importantly, a diabetic patient. MOE is primarily caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection and occurs most commonly in elderly diabetic patients or immunocompromised individuals.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma : This typically presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, conductive hearing loss due to eustachian tube dysfunction, and cranial nerve palsies (particularly CN V and VI) from skull base invasion. Primary symptoms would be in the nasopharynx rather than the external ear, and there would not be granulation tissue in the external ear canal.
  • • Option B. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • • Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media : This involves a long-standing infection of the middle ear with tympanic membrane perforation and persistent discharge. While it can cause bone erosion and complications like facial palsy, it wouldn't present with granulation tissue in the external ear canal as the primary site of disease is the middle ear. The extreme pain described is also more characteristic of MOE.
  • • Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media
  • • Option D. Acute suppurative otitis media : This is an acute infection of the middle ear presenting with otalgia, fever, and sometimes otorrhea if the tympanic membrane ruptures. It doesn't cause bony erosion or facial nerve palsy in its typical presentation, and would generally respond to appropriate antibiotic therapy, unlike the case described.
  • • Option D. Acute suppurative otitis media

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Malignant otitis externa should be strongly suspected in elderly diabetic patients presenting with severe otalgia, otorrhea unresponsive to therapy, granulation tissue in the ear canal, and complications like facial nerve palsy or evidence of bony erosion.

questions.text: Following are mature defense mechanisms, EXCEPT: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Denial is classified as an immature defense mechanism, not a mature one. It involves the refusal to accept reality or facts, thereby protecting the individual from experiencing painful emotions or external threats. While it may offer short-term emotional relief, over time it can impair functioning by distorting reality and preventing adaptive coping.
  • • In contrast, mature defense mechanisms are considered healthy and adaptive ways of managing internal conflict and stress. They help individuals handle difficult emotions without distorting reality or harming others.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Altruism: It’s a mature defense mechanism. Option B. Humor: It’s a mature defense mechanism. Option C. Anticipation: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • • Option A. Altruism: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • • Option A. Altruism:
  • • Option B. Humor: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • • Option B. Humor:
  • • Option C. Anticipation: It’s a mature defense mechanism.
  • • Option C. Anticipation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Defense mechanisms lie on a spectrum from immature to mature. The following are mature defense mechanisms-
  • ➤ Sublimation: Transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse into socially acceptable behaviour. E.g. A middle-aged man with unacceptable sexual desire becomes a painter and starts making nude paintings Anticipation: Preparing in advance for an unpleasant situation. E.g. A student plans all his arguments comprehensively before telling his father about a bad exam result. Humour: Use of comedy to deal with an unpleasant situation. E.g Two medical students joked and laughed at themselves after getting humiliated by the examiner during the viva Altruism: Use of a social cause to deal with own emotions. E.g. After losing his son in an accident while driving drunk, a man launched an anti-drunk driving campaign, educating others about the dangers of driving under the influence. Suppression: A voluntary decision not to think about an event for some time and avoid the accompanying emotions. E.g. A highly stressed medical student, facing an upcoming entrance exam, chooses to take a one-day break and doesnt think about the exam at all. It is the only voluntary/conscious defense mechanism
  • ➤ Sublimation: Transformation of a socially unacceptable impulse into socially acceptable behaviour. E.g. A middle-aged man with unacceptable sexual desire becomes a painter and starts making nude paintings
  • ➤ Anticipation: Preparing in advance for an unpleasant situation. E.g. A student plans all his arguments comprehensively before telling his father about a bad exam result.
  • ➤ Humour: Use of comedy to deal with an unpleasant situation. E.g Two medical students joked and laughed at themselves after getting humiliated by the examiner during the viva
  • ➤ Altruism: Use of a social cause to deal with own emotions. E.g. After losing his son in an accident while driving drunk, a man launched an anti-drunk driving campaign, educating others about the dangers of driving under the influence.
  • ➤ Suppression: A voluntary decision not to think about an event for some time and avoid the accompanying emotions. E.g. A highly stressed medical student, facing an upcoming entrance exam, chooses to take a one-day break and doesnt think about the exam at all. It is the only voluntary/conscious defense mechanism

questions.text: Methotrexate is a chemotherapeutic agent used in the treatment of breast cancer. It works by inhibiting the synthesis of which nucleotide? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) TMP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, leading to a reduction in thymine monophosphate (TMP) synthesis, which is critical for DNA synthesis. This makes it effective in the treatment of cancers, including breast cancer

questions.text: Mr. X got married to Ms. Y in 1999. They had overall two children - Ms. M in 2002 and Ms. N in 2009. Mr. X’s father was a bank employee who moved in, post-retirement in 2008, with them along with his wife. Which stage of the family cycle do they belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Complete extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Complete extension stage of family cycle starts after last childbirth and continues until first child leaves home.
  • ➤ Family system in INDIA
  • ➤ Family system in INDIA
  • ➤ Family cycle

questions.text: Infections of the middle ear can extend to the brain through all of the following routes, except: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Spread through Lymphatic Channels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Middle ear infections do not spread to the brain through lymphatic channels because there are no lymphatic connections between the middle ear and intracranial structures. The brain and cranial cavity lack a traditional lymphatic system. Infection from the middle ear to the brain occurs through other routes including direct bone erosion, preformed pathways, or hematogenous spread.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Direct Bony Invasion : This is a common route of intracranial spread of middle ear infection. Cholesteatoma or chronic infection can erode the tegmen tympani (roof of middle ear), allowing infection to spread to the middle cranial fossa causing extradural or subdural abscess. Similarly, erosion of the posterior wall can lead to cerebellar abscess.
  • • Option A. Direct Bony Invasion
  • • Option B. Oval or Round Window : These are preformed pathways through which infection can spread from the middle ear to the inner ear (labyrinthitis), and then to the internal auditory canal and cerebellopontine angle through the cochlear aqueduct or internal auditory canal. The subarachnoid space can be accessed through the cochlear aqueduct, which connects the scala tympani with the subarachnoid space.
  • • Option B. Oval or Round Window
  • • Option C. Spread via Bloodstream : Hematogenous spread is another valid route where infection spreads through venous channels, particularly through emissary veins or by thrombophlebitis of the sigmoid sinus. This can lead to lateral sinus thrombosis, meningitis, or brain abscess.
  • • Option C. Spread via Bloodstream

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While middle ear infections can spread to intracranial structures through direct bone erosion, preformed pathways (oval/round windows), and bloodstream, there is no lymphatic route for such spread since the brain lacks traditional lymphatics.

questions.text: The image regarding health care system levels in the country. Correct arrangement about the levels of health care is: (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Medical colleges and hospitals are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level

options.label: B
options.text: Subcentre and PHC are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level

options.label: C
options.text: CHC is primary level, Subcentre and PHC are secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level

options.label: D
options.text: CHC is primary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are secondary level, Subcentre and PHC are tertiary level

questions.correct_answer: B. Subcentre and PHC are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subcentre and PHC are primary level, CHC is secondary level, Medical colleges and hospitals are tertiary level

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The three-tier healthcare delivery system in India consists of:
  • ➤ Primary level: Sub-centers and PHCs (First contact point) Secondary level: CHCs (First referral level) Tertiary level: Medical colleges and hospitals (Second referral level)
  • ➤ Primary level: Sub-centers and PHCs (First contact point)
  • ➤ Primary level:
  • ➤ Secondary level: CHCs (First referral level)
  • ➤ Secondary level:
  • ➤ Tertiary level: Medical colleges and hospitals (Second referral level)
  • ➤ Tertiary level:

questions.text: Goldenhar syndrome is associated with abnormal development of which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.correct_answer: A. First and Second Branchial Arches
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Goldenhar syndrome, also known as oculo-auriculo-vertebral spectrum (OAVS) or hemifacial microsomia, results from abnormal development of the first and second branchial arches during embryonic development. These structures form during the 4th week of embryonic life and contribute to the development of facial structures. The disruption in development leads to the characteristic features of Goldenhar syndrome, including facial asymmetry, ear anomalies (microtia, anotia, preauricular tags or pits), vertebral anomalies, and ocular manifestations (epibulbar dermoids, colobomas).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. First and Second Branchial Pouches - Incorrect. While branchial pouches are involved in the development of structures in the head and neck region, Goldenhar syndrome specifically involves malformation of the branchial arches rather than the pouches. Branchial pouches give rise to structures such as the middle ear cavity, tonsils, and parathyroid glands.
  • • Option B. First and Second Branchial Pouches
  • • Option C. Second and Third Branchial Arches - Incorrect. Goldenhar syndrome primarily affects the first and second branchial arches, not the second and third. The third branchial arch contributes to structures like the hyoid bone (along with the 2nd) and stylopharyngeus muscle.
  • • Option C. Second and Third Branchial Arches
  • • Option D. Second and Third Branchial Pouches - Incorrect. Goldenhar syndrome involves branchial arches rather than pouches, and specifically affects the first and second arches, not the second and third pouches.
  • • Option D. Second and Third Branchial Pouches

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Goldenhar syndrome (oculo-auriculo-vertebral spectrum) results from abnormal development of the first and second branchial arches, leading to characteristic facial asymmetry, ear anomalies, vertebral defects, and ocular manifestations.

questions.text: Myxoedema Madness most frequently presents as: ( NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In its most severe form, myxedema madness a term describing the psychiatric manifestation of severe hypothyroidism can present with a range of symptoms, including paranoia, depression, hypomania, and hallucinations . Auditory hallucinations are the most common form in psychiatric conditions generally, making auditory hallucination plus paranoia the most characteristic presentation in this context.
  • • myxedema madness
  • • severe hypothyroidism
  • • paranoia, depression, hypomania, and hallucinations
  • • Auditory hallucinations
  • • auditory hallucination plus paranoia
  • • This combination can closely mimic paranoid psychosis or schizophrenia , particularly in elderly women with undiagnosed hypothyroidism. The pathophysiology involves thyroid hormone deficiency leading to widespread alterations in neurotransmitter balance, cerebral metabolism , and cognitive function , producing a full spectrum of mood and psychotic symptoms.
  • • paranoid psychosis
  • • schizophrenia
  • • neurotransmitter balance, cerebral metabolism
  • • cognitive function
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Visual Hallucination and Depression: While depression is commonly associated with hypothyroidism, visual hallucinations are less typical features in myxedema madness. Auditory hallucinations remain the most likely type when psychosis occurs. Option C. Tactile Hallucination and Paranoia: Tactile hallucinations are more characteristic of substance-induced psychosis , such as that caused by stimulants (e.g., cocaine or methamphetamine), and are not commonly linked to hypothyroid states. Option D. Paranoia and Depression: Both symptoms are indeed noted in myxedema madness, but this option omits hallucinations , which are part of the more complete and classic presentation in severe cases.
  • • Option B. Visual Hallucination and Depression: While depression is commonly associated with hypothyroidism, visual hallucinations are less typical features in myxedema madness. Auditory hallucinations remain the most likely type when psychosis occurs.
  • • Option B. Visual Hallucination and Depression:
  • • Option C. Tactile Hallucination and Paranoia: Tactile hallucinations are more characteristic of substance-induced psychosis , such as that caused by stimulants (e.g., cocaine or methamphetamine), and are not commonly linked to hypothyroid states.
  • • Option C. Tactile Hallucination and Paranoia:
  • • substance-induced psychosis
  • • Option D. Paranoia and Depression: Both symptoms are indeed noted in myxedema madness, but this option omits hallucinations , which are part of the more complete and classic presentation in severe cases.
  • • Option D. Paranoia and Depression:
  • • omits hallucinations

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myxedema madness presents with a constellation of psychiatric symptoms, most characteristically paranoia with hallucinations (typically auditory), sometimes alongside depression and hypomania. Always consider hypothyroidism in cases of new-onset psychosis in older adults, especially when accompanied by physical signs like cold intolerance, bradycardia, dry skin, and weight gain.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with symptoms of bone pain, anemia, hypercalcemia, and renal impairment. A bone marrow biopsy confirms the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The patient is started on a treatment regimen. Which of the following treatments is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bortezomib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bortezomib , a proteasome inhibitor used in the treatment of multiple myeloma, is most likely associated with the reactivation of herpes zoster due to its immunosuppressive properties. This highlights the importance of monitoring patients on such treatments for signs of viral reactivation
  • ➤ Bortezomib

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hypocalcemia after consuming an unknown substance. There was presence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Which of the following substances was most likely consumed? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ethylene glycol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning should be suspected in patients presenting with high anion gap metabolic acidosis, hypocalcemia, and symptoms resembling alcohol intoxication. The formation of oxalate crystals and the subsequent hypocalcemia are key features that differentiate it from other toxic ingestions.

questions.text: A patient with HIV who is currently on antiretroviral therapy consisting of zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine is diagnosed with tuberculosis. Considering potential drug interactions, which of the following TB drugs should be changed in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rifampicin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For HIV and TB cotreatment:
  • ➤ If a person is on the TLE regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, efavirenz), it does not interact with rifampicin. The regimen can continue unchanged even if rifampicin is given. If the person is on the TLD regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, dolutegravir), the dose of dolutegravir should be doubled when rifampicin is used, while the rest of the regimen remains the same. If the person is taking a protease inhibitor or nevirapine , rifampicin should be avoided. Instead, rifampicin should be replaced with rifabutin.
  • ➤ If a person is on the TLE regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, efavirenz), it does not interact with rifampicin. The regimen can continue unchanged even if rifampicin is given.
  • ➤ TLE regimen
  • ➤ If the person is on the TLD regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, dolutegravir), the dose of dolutegravir should be doubled when rifampicin is used, while the rest of the regimen remains the same.
  • ➤ TLD regimen
  • ➤ If the person is taking a protease inhibitor or nevirapine , rifampicin should be avoided. Instead, rifampicin should be replaced with rifabutin.
  • ➤ protease inhibitor
  • ➤ nevirapine

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of burning sensation during urination and a purulent discharge from the penis for the past 5 days. He has had unprotected sexual intercourse with a new partner two weeks ago. On examination, the urethral meatus is erythematous, and there is a noticeable purulent discharge. A Gram stain of the discharge reveals intracellular gram-negative diplococci. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no known drug allergies. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Benzathine penicillin G 2.4 Million Units intramuscularly

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cefixime 400 mg orally

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cefixime 400 mg orally is an effective oral treatment option for gonorrhea, particularly in patients who prefer to avoid injections. The presence of intracellular gram-negative diplococci in a symptomatic patient strongly suggests gonococcal infection, requiring prompt and appropriate antibiotic therapy.
  • ➤ Cefixime 400 mg orally

questions.text: Which of the following guidelines are true for the client post-vasectomy? (FMGE JAN 2025)

options.label: A
options.text: Barrier methods for 4 months and then Semen analysis to confirm

options.label: B
options.text: Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm

options.label: C
options.text: Barrier methods for 4 months with no need to come back

options.label: D
options.text: Barrier methods for 3 months with no need to come back

questions.correct_answer: B. Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Barrier methods for 3 months and then Semen analysis to confirm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Post-vasectomy guidelines require:
  • ➤ Use of barrier methods for 3 months Mandatory semen analysis after 3 months to confirm success of sterilization
  • ➤ Use of barrier methods for 3 months
  • ➤ Mandatory semen analysis after 3 months to confirm success of sterilization

questions.text: Which ganglia is affected due to the involvement of the nerve located at the marked area? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pterygopalatine ganglion is located in the pterygopalatine fossa and is involved in the parasympathetic innervation of the lacrimal, nasal, and palatine glands. This ganglion is specifically affected by involvement in the region marked in the skull image.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presents with a positive Hitzelberger sign. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vestibular schwannoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A positive Hitzelberger sign indicates hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in the external auditory canal. This sign is pathognomonic for acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma). Hitzelberger sign occurs when the nervus intermedius (sensory branch of facial nerve) is compressed in the internal auditory canal by the growing tumor. It is considered the first sign that indicates facial nerve involvement in acoustic neuroma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Mastoiditis: This is an infection of the mastoid air cells that presents with postauricular pain, tenderness, and swelling. Signs include "ironing of mastoid surface" (smooth & shiny look), mastoid tenderness, and sagging of the posterior meatal wall. Hitzelberger sign is not associated with mastoiditis.
  • • Option B. Mastoiditis:
  • • Option C. Bell's palsy: This is an idiopathic facial paralysis presenting with unilateral facial weakness. While it affects the facial nerve, Bell's palsy doesn't typically cause hypoesthesia of the posterior canal wall. Bell's palsy affects the motor component of the facial nerve, not the sensory fibers that would produce Hitzelberger sign.
  • • Option C. Bell's palsy:
  • • Option D. Middle ear cholesteatoma: This is "skin in the wrong place" - keratinizing squamous epithelium in the middle ear. It can cause ossicular destruction and various complications, but Hitzelberger sign is not one of them. Cholesteatoma affects the middle ear structures, not the internal auditory canal where compression causing Hitzelberger sign occurs.
  • • Option D. Middle ear cholesteatoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hitzelberger sign (decreased sensation in the posterior meatal wall) is pathognomonic for vestibular schwannoma and represents early involvement of the facial nerve as the tumor compresses the nervus intermedius in the internal auditory canal.

questions.text: Caffeine is a widely used stimulant that promotes wakefulness. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this effect? (NEET PG 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Increased discharge of norepinephrine from the locus ceruleus

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Adenosine antagonism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Caffeine is a widely used stimulant that promotes wakefulness through three main mechanisms:
  • ➤ Caffeine
  • ➤ Inhibits phosphodiesterase enzyme. Acts as an adenosine A1 receptor antagonist. Releases norepinephrine from the locus coeruleus.
  • ➤ Inhibits phosphodiesterase enzyme.
  • ➤ Acts as an adenosine A1 receptor antagonist.
  • ➤ Releases norepinephrine from the locus coeruleus.
  • ➤ Caffeine promotes wakefulness primarily through the antagonism of adenosine receptors, blocking the sleep-inducing effects of adenosine and resulting in increased alertness
